ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In every class we went over a PowerPoint of past watercolor artists and their work, where the professor would discuss the techniques the artist uses and also just talk about the piece as art. I gained a greater appreciation for art and a deeper understanding of the subject just by being exposed to these discussions of art pieces throughout history. I also got a lot of practice in watercolor painting which was fun because I did not have much experience before.
Basics of watercolor as well as some of the famous water color artists in history

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I don't like the powerpoint presentations. I don't feel like it teaches me anything about the artist.

Strengths: exposes you to art in a new way, professor is passionate, small seminar style of class is nice, fun in-class painting activities
Weaknesses: essays due throughout the course
I enjoyed the format of the course and painting in general

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you need a chill FYS for fun, go ahead and take it. You might improve in painting because you'll be making two paintings every week. That sounds like a lot, I know, but it's a good refresher after other classes and bunch of psets.

Even though it is a seminar, the professor conducts the class more like a lecture so student participation is mostly just attendance, meaning you dont have to talk in class much if you dont want to. It is a fun class if you want to paint more, half of the three hour class each week was spent painting outdoors on campus which was fun. The only bad part is the three essays due throughout the semester, it is excessive for a course that is not a writing credit and the professor often nitpicks on the writing aspect more than the actual art analysis. Painting for this class was a welcome break from the workload of other courses and it was nice to change things up from studying at a computer. Sometimes the weekly paintings due for homework were hard to keep up with along with homework from other classes. I would recommend if you are passionate about learning more about art and watercolor painting.

Yes, I thoroughly enjoyed the class as we were able to do something different from the typical academic rigor. Painting has a therapeutic nature to it to me personally and I believe it would to others as well.
